title: 103_s579
content: The "Equity for Congress Act" covers Congress and presidential appointees. The "Equity for Congress Act" extends rights and protections to Congress employees, applying laws such as Title VII of the Civil Rights Act and the Fair Labor Standards Act. The "Equity for Congress Act" extends rights and protections to congressional employees, allowing them to enforce laws such as Title VII of the Civil Rights Act and the Fair Labor Standards Act through administrative actions. The "Equity for Congress Act" allows congressional employees to enforce laws through administrative actions and civil lawsuits against Congress or their employer. The "Equity for Congress Act" allows civil actions to enforce laws with statutory and procedural requirements, venue options in any court of competent jurisdiction, and relief in the form of equitable relief against Congress or congressional employers. The "Equity for Congress Act" allows civil actions to enforce laws with statutory and procedural requirements, venue options in any court of competent jurisdiction, and relief in the form of damages and fees against Congress. SEC. 3 of the "Equity for Congress Act" extends rights and protections under the Americans with Disabilities Act to matters other than employment. Enforcement can be through administrative or civil actions. SEC. 4 of the "Equity for Congress Act" extends information rights and protections to Congress under section 552a of title 5, United States Code. Enforcement can be through administrative or civil actions. SEC. 5 of the "Equity for Congress Act" extends rights and protections to Congress for investigation of congressional improprieties. Enforcement can be through administrative or civil actions. SEC. 6 amends the Rules of the Senate regarding bills, resolutions, or amendments that exempt Congress from general applicability requirements. SEC. 7 amends the Rules of the House of Representatives. SEC. 7 of the "Equity for Congress Act" amends Rule XXIV of the House of Representatives to require a three-fifths vote for any bill exempting Congress from general applicability requirements. The "Equity for Congress Act" defines a "congressional employer" as a supervisor in the Senate or a Member of the House of Representatives overseeing assistants or staff members. The "Equity for Congress Act" designates various individuals to oversee different staff members within the House of Representatives, including subcommittee members, Majority and Minority Leaders, officers of the House, the Architect of the Capitol, and the Director of the Congressional Budget Office. The "Equity for Congress Act" designates individuals to oversee staff members in the House of Representatives, including employees of specific offices like the General Accounting Office, Government Printing Office, Library of Congress, Office of Technology Assessment, and United States Botanic Gardens. The term "congressional employee" refers to employees of a congressional employer, while a "similarly situated complaining party" is defined as such. The term "similarly situated complaining party" is defined as a governmental complaining party in cases with a separate enforcement mechanism, or as a complaining party in cases without such a mechanism. SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE: This Act will be enforced 120 days after its enactment.
